conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to use the ideal gas law and the fact that for an ideal gas, the product of pressure (p) and volume (V) divided by the temperature (T) is a constant (nR, where n is the number of moles and R is the gas constant). This can be expressed as: \( \frac{pV}{T} = \text{constant} \)
Given: State A: \( p_A = 1.0 \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa} \), \( V_A = 6.0 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3 \), \( T_A = 27^\circ \text{C} = 300 \, \text{K} \)

premise: Using the ideal gas law for state A: \( \frac{p_A V_A}{T_A} = \frac{(1.0 \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa}) \times (6.0 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3)}{300 \, \text{K}} \)
For state B, using the same constant: \( \frac{p_B V_B}{T_B} = 2 \, \text{Pa} \cdot \text{m}^3 / \text{K} \)
conclusion: Substitute the values for \( p_B \) and \( V_B \): \( \frac{(2.0 \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa}) \times (6.0 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3)}{T_B} = 2 \, \text{Pa} \cdot \text{m}^3 / \text{K} \)
